LineBet
4.0 out of 5 stars Great if you are organized up front
Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2014
Verified Purchase
Since Amazon began offering free unlimited photo storage for prime members, I've been backing up all my pics from various computers and from archive drives to the Amazon Cloud.

WHAT I LIKE ...

* the price, free for Amazon prime customers

* pictures are saved at their full size (unlike the free storage on Google Drive)

* relatively easy to use

* deleted photos remain online in a deleted folder, so that they can later be restored if necessary. There is also a "permanently delete" option.

* ability to view photos in chronological order. While traveling, I typically will take photos on my iphone, my tablet, a SLR camera and a pocket camera. Amazon stores just enough metadata to be able to offer you the option of displaying photos chronologically. So, upon returning from a trip, I can upload all the various devices separately and still view the pics in chronological order, without having to first combine the photos from different devices into a single folder.

and the most significant benefit for me:

* my entire photo library is now available for viewing from all my portable devices! Additionally, the cache utilization can be set so that recently displayed photos remain viewable even without wi-fi access.

.
WHAT I DISLIKE ...

* time to upload. At the 15 mps speed in my home, I get just over 100 photos an hour uploaded.

* lack of any way to organize uploaded files. Photos can't be moved between folders nor can folders be renamed. And unless you want to have multiple directories labeled "101Canon," you should name your directories before you start to upload. The same goes for any file names.

* while uploading, the software does not display the names of the files being sent or of those folders in the queue, only the total number of photos queued and the number already transferred.

* the need to pull any video files out of the folders before uploading. Video storage on Amazon is not free (beyond your initial free 10 GB) and, more importantly, those larger video files take FOREVER to upload.

* poor photo editing capabilities. If you'd like to do any editing beyond the basic crop or contrast, I'd suggest you do it elsewhere, before you upload.

* limited metadata displayed. You get file name, date taken, date added, file size and image size. Photos are organized by album and can be sorted, either within an album or globally, by either date taken or date uploaded. (I am hoping that Amazon has actually stored all the metadata in the photos I've uploaded and, with enough suggestions to do so, will begin to display all of it.)

* occasional uploading issues. 1) If the uploader discovers that a photo being sent has the same name as one already in the target directory, it will stop and await user input before continuing, which sometimes makes it hard to just walk away during the process. 2) an occasion photo will not upload; in these instances, the uploader continues and provides an error message with the photo name. 3) on a couple of occasions, uploading has stopped without explanation beyond a simple error message. In those cases, I've had to open the directory on the Cloud drive, determine what picture in what folder was the last to upload and then upload that directory again, making sure to first remove those photos from the directory that have already been transferred.

* occasional duplicates. If you happen to have the same image stored on multiple devices and you upload the image from each device you'll wind up with two copies of the same photo on the cloud (assuming each is coming from a folder with a different name).

.
Given these limitations, here's the process I've been following with any new photos:

1) Download the photos to my PC
2) Delete and/or edit photos on the PC, using Picasa or any other full-featured photo editor
3) Save the remaining photos in a folder with a descriptive name
4) Upload that folder to the Amazon Cloud, usually overnight. For now, I've been keeping the original directory on my PC, as an additional backup.

Despite a few shortcomings, I view photo backup on the Amazon Cloud as a no-brainer, especially for Amazon Prime customers. Unlimited free storage of full-size photos is a deal that can't be beat. No more worry about keeping multiple backups at separate locations. I've already lost one set of family photos to a failed HDD and don't intend to lose another.

Mike Powers
3.0 out of 5 stars "Prime Photos from Amazon" has a lot of potential to become truly outstanding – but it’s not there yet.
Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2017
Verified Purchase
I’ve used several different apps to store my photos and videos in the cloud, with varying degrees of success. I decided to give “Prime Photos from Amazon” a spin, to see if it offers any advantages over the other cloud photo storage apps I’ve used in the past…

In two words: it doesn’t. It does essentially everything that the other apps do, only not as well. It was very slow to upload the 1,300 photos I have on my phone – it took nearly four hours to upload them from my Galaxy S7. “Prime Photos from Amazon” offers a basic set of tools for organizing photos into “People,” “Places,” and “Things,” but not much else. I can keep my photos for private viewing, or I can share them with others.

“Prime Photos from Amazon” also offers a useful set of photo editing tools, which can be used for adjusting color, brightness, and contrast; adding frames and text; and creating memes.

One feature of “Prime Photos from Amazon” I find very frustrating. When it first uploaded my photos, it captured images of different people’s faces from group photos and set them aside in a section called “People.” Many of these images are of people I don’t know, and many are too blurry or grainy to use. Yet, the app provides me with no way to edit or delete those individual “People” images that I don’t want. All I can do is delete the entire photo from which these “People” images are drawn, and that is unacceptable to me.

“Prime Photos from Amazon” was released in April 2017. Because it is so new, I get the feeling it is still a work in progress. It has a lot of potential to become a truly outstanding cloud photo storage and editing app – but it’s not there yet. Right now, it’s strictly average fare. Recommended (for now) only as a backup for other, better apps of the same type.

Michael Mac
4.0 out of 5 stars I Love It! Just Wish It Could Have Just A Bit More...
Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
Verified Purchase
I absolutely love how it is UNLIMITED for pictures (can't/hard to find that anywhere else!) And it's pretty cool that it has the corresponding phone app to backup your photos automatically too. It is really nice to have peace of mind that my precious memories will be safe in a cloud if anything happens to the hard copies...all of this is good for Amazon and as a retention strategy because now I don't think I can ever pass/cancel my Prime membership lest I lose this very advantageous service/method...

5GB for videos is a bit restrictive though...I mean, I understand how much space it could potentially take, but memories are easily on videos as they can be/are on photos...and $60 for unlimited videos (as well as other files) is STEEP...hard to justify...I mean, how about a $10-$15 3-month subscription versus a single option of a full $60 for the year (no in-between option)...

And for pictures (in the Photos & Videos section) to be only sorted by "date taken" and "date uploaded" is also rather limited as well. Sometimes dates on camera's are wrong or never set up, or people upload in bulk (like I am); makes sorting when the files were uploaded all come up in the same section anyways. Would be nice to have sorted by folder, name, exposure (maybe?), device (camera), dimensions, location (if geo-tagged), size, tags, even color!, etc...

Also, I wish that the program (on PC) didn't only upload only 4 files at a time...If a user has enough bandwidth, the program should allow for the max possible...Also, it would be nice to be able to skip certain (big) files and/or only/filter upload by file type or something...

TL;DR -- This is an amazing service/option (if you have Prime membership) to have. Nothing I listed are "deal breakers," but it shows that there is still a little bit left to be desired; though that will not stop me from fully using this service.

UPDATE (8/1/17): So Amazon has done much with Prime Photos since I wrote my review. I believe Prime Photos was rather in its infancy at the time of writing. And as I see some people are still reading this review, I decided it'd be good to put in an update to show what's different/better and/or my opinion on matters.

So, since then, it looks like Amazon has inputted more than just the 2 choice of either free but limited (5GB) or unlimited but expensive ($60 at the time). Apparently, it's a free 5 GB, $12 for 100 GB, $60 for 1 TB (still), and $120 for 30 TB. I still really believe doing a very cheap 3 month type subscription than a yearly one (broken down = $1/month for 100 GB total). I'm betting people are not so willing to commit to a whole year subscription and not be able to back out within the year or is forced to wait til the year is over to cancel.
It is nice that you can now sort and filter by objects in the collection of pictures (i.e. dog, cat, lamp, drinks, cup, party, etc.). Still, I think it would be nice to add the option of sorting by camera, dimension, size, and even color! If it were to include those, I think it would be really helpful because in a collection reaching 5 to 6 figures, those can really narrow down if I was trying to seek certain ones.
But I absolutely LOVE the facial recognition and sorting by face! I know it's done in other photo archiving/backup services, but it's still really nice to see it implemented here. It's still doesn't run perfectly (keeps re-arranging, keeps dropping ID after reconfiguring/rearranging, assigning myriad babies and older asian ladies bulked together, etc.), but when it does hit, it makes for a nice and curious feature.
It still hasn't really made it capable of uploading more than 4 files, nor the capability to upload only picture or document or other type files (it would upload a 1.4GB video, reaching the max 5GB, and then skipping all other documents, .pdf's, and scans). These are sorely missing out.
It is nice to have it automatically "syncing" with the Amazon folder on my computer. I just put my pictures and picture folders in there, and they automatically upload and backup to the Amazon Drive and available in Prime Photos. Keeps it simple, easy, and rather mindless to keep from worrying about another thing...

Still, in the end, this is a wonderful, GREAT service to have considering it's no more additional $ to have with your PRIME membership. And just as before, none of these are "deal-breakers" again, just that there are still things left to be desired. But I can't think of any reason why this isn't anything but beneficial to PRIME members!

LKF
4.0 out of 5 stars Simple, almost foolproof photo and video storage across many devices.
Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2014
Verified Purchase
If you are concerned about storing and retrieving unlimited amounts of photos and videos across many devices, this may be the application for you. Let's talk about what it doesn't do first: 1) There is no obvious way to search photos or videos based upon key words or facial recognition 2) You cannot edit the photo in the app as you can in Picassa 3)You can't quickly forward or email the photo from the app-- you need to save it on your local device first 4) if the app isn't actively loaded on your device, it obviously isn't going to sync your photos until the app is running.

What it DOES do is quickly collect all of your photos across any device it is loaded on and arrange thumbnails in either date loaded or date taken order (your choice.) It uploads your pictures and videos to Amazon's cloud device and if you are a Prime member, there is no charge for the storage. YOu can also upload anything else you like to the 50GB of free space that you are given--so in that way it is like a Google drive.

I have tried the product on several different platforms-- it runs well on Windows 7, XP, Android and IOS.

IN summary, a great way to make sure you don't lose any photos --so long as you remember to keep the app logged in!

Amazon Customer
3.0 out of 5 stars You get what you pay for: Basic Image Repository With No Bells Or Whistles.
Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2015
Verified Purchase
Uploaded a few Gb of pictures as a test.
Site is fairly quick on a decent internet connection, both up and downloading, and browsing.
If you take RAW camera pictures with Cameras that are older than a few years, they will not be accepted as images but as Data Files! This means you need to sign up for the unlimited data subscription. However, BIG Tiff and PSD/RAW (Adobe Photoshop files, 50-300Mb ea) are recognized as image files.
Other than that, uploading was no problem, but pay attention to the option for destination directory!
If you don't, you have to manually move the files to a directory that you create either before or after the transfer.

Place your files in Directories based on your details you usually search by!
Sorting on site is SUPER BASIC, either by: File Name, Date Added/Date Modified or Size.
Date Added is useless unless you equate Date Added with Date Created (you'd have to upload images straight from your Camera as you take them. Otherwise the File Name has to have the Date in it, but still would not sort by Date Created if you have several cameras you use that same day since each camera would have a distinct name.
Today each camera created picture (unless scanned) has EXIF data that contains the Date Created/Taken, Camera Name and much more that could be used for more detailed searches like typical computers are capable of.

Knowing these limitations before you start uploading files helps in setting up a system that allows you to find your pictures again.
In time I hope this storage ends up looking more like a simple photo search, sort and retrieval archive rather than the shoe-boxes full of pictures of yesteryear.

Scott L.
3.0 out of 5 stars Free cellular phone backup is good. Program lacks other features.
Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2015
Verified Purchase
First of all, Kudos to Amazon for allowing Prime members to store unlimited photos. It's a nice membership benefit, and provides a free (and safe) backup for the photos on our family's computer and cellular phones.

As for the app itself - it does send photos to Amazon's "free" (with prime membership) cloud storage. And it does a good job of this. If this is all you want, it's a five star app.

However, if you're like our family, you've got a file of photos. The only way to retrieve them is by scrolling through the photos in date order. And if your photo lacks EXIF data, it is based on the date the photo is uploaded. Another annoyance? I've tried deleting a few accidental photos from Amazon from this app several times. But, even after confirming that, yes, I want to delete these photos from both my phone and Amazon, these photos just keep coming back from the dead!

If you're looking for a program that will help you organize hundreds of photographs - this program won't do it. As I've said, you can't even reliably delete photos. But it's still a good photo backup service.

Kindle Customer
2.0 out of 5 stars Feature Incomplete
Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2015
Verified Purchase
Giving it 2 stars because it does do what it says, but no more. It is lacking features you expect from a modern app.
What it does:
- Uploads images and videos from your camera to your cloud drive

What it does not do:
- Upload automatically in the background. You have to manually start the app, which means your files won't upload until you remember to start to process. I couldn't find a setting to run in the background like other clients I've used.
- Allow you to browse files by folders. You want to look at your pictures? Here they are. All of them. Good luck with that. OK, it does sort by date, but that isn't that useful.
- Allow you to control where they upload. I get that with an automatic upload you don't really need to change the location a lot. But it would be nice if I had some control over where they go. It just dumps them in Pictures\FolderNameBasedOnCamera\Camera\Pictures

Amazon is late to the full cloud drive space and it shows. They seem to be taking a page from the Google Drive handbook. Here's your space, don't bother using the tools we give you as they are useless.

The facial recognition is also better in Google.

My 2 cents. I hope you find this helpful.
